Feature: Are there specific vocabularies for hunting or use in the presence of avoidance kin?
Comment: There is no specific vocabulary, but there is a taboo on asking someone who goes hunting where he is going. He must just go silently. If they discuss to  go hunting, they say: tomorrow we go close to our ears. When we go fishing, it is also not allowed to ask where we go.

Feature: Is there ritual speech?
Does the ritual speech involve parallellisms, dual symbolic categories?
Comment: an example of ritual speech is  given; transcript and translation in a separate word file.

Feature: Is the ritual language known by everyone (or just by traditional leaders)?
Comment: Only traditional leaders know it.

Feature: Are there ritual songs?
Comment: An example of a poem is given, used when the parents of a young couple meet to discuss the future marriage. Transcript and translation in seperate word file.

Feature: Are there ritual dances?
Is the language of the ritual songs a language you understand?
Is the language of the ritual songs a foreign language?
Comment: Mostly from Western Pantar as we fled from there.

Feature: Do women and men dance together?
Comment: Women in the middle, men around them. Clip 9; 2:00 vv explanation when they lego-lego and what they dance, and how many rounds, when a bride arrives. In that case they are only allowed to dance after sunrise. In other cases, e.g. when a new house is built they can also dance at night.

Feature: Are there traditional ceremonies where men and women must be separated?
Comment: Discussions of bride price are only done by the men.

Feature: Is there a ceremony relating to planting/harvesting?
Comment: There is a song they sing when planting the garden.  On Clip 9; 6 mins, they sing it together. There is a song they sing when harvesting, Clip 9; 7; and a song they sing when going home after harvesting; clip 9; 10 mins; nice!!

Feature: Did your ancestors arrive in boats?
Comment: On Clip 2, 6:42-10 mins they explain that the Teiwa originate from Western Pantar. When there was a flood (tsunami) there, the people got up and left, and went to stay in Lebang. At the time there were also other people there. The Kakalau came following us. The Kakamoto stayed in West Pantar. Over here, there were the Lauwan. We had been looking for a place to stay till Bakalang, but did not find it, and when we met the Lauwan they said we could stay. We followed the river up to Lebang and stayed there.

Feature: Does sacrifice involve feeding of ancestors?
Is there/are  there (a) ritual place(s)?
Comment: place for lego-lego, building adat meetings (rumah sulung); uur mount of stones functioning as altar.

Feature: Did your ancestors arrive as sea animals? (shark, crocodile, turtle, dolphin)
Is there a myth about the origin of the people?
Comment: The Lau Wan clan grew out of the earth. About the other clans, we don't know.

Feature: Are there traditional religious leaders or specialists?
Comment: In the past, before Christianity, moko were given food. There were one or two people who knew how to say the formula that goes with it. Clip 10, 4 mins What is the name of this person?

Feature: Are there traditional drinks, or stimulants?
Comment: tuax 'tuak van enau palm', sirih pinang.

Feature: Is there a traditional sacrifice place?
Comment: dor 'altar', mount of stones. The blood of a chicken or goat must go on top of it. An animal sacrify used to be given to ask for rain (after planting) so that the crop will be good. Nowadays we don't do this anymore (not allowed in christianity).

Feature: Are there rituals around birth?
Comment: See the answer to question 9.

Feature: Are there rituals around death?
Comment: The women lament using a traditional song. Nowadays the body is burried after one or two days but in the past it was kept for 6, or 12 or 17 days. People would eat in the vicinity even if the body was rotting. Nowadays they would not come anymore to eat next to a decaying body. The body was put on a bamboo platform. The head or hips of a dead man had to be supported by a gong or a large xxxx plate (Clip 10, 10:10 what kind of plate?). Relatives bring pigs, goats, and many kain, which are all buried. A burial feast will be held for 40 days. No food is put in the grave (the Kroku in Bukalabang do this).

Feature: Are there seasonal rituals apart from planting and harvesting, for example is there a ritual to ask for rain? Or other rituals?
Comment: See answer to 11.6.

Feature: Do women traditionally weave?
Is there traditional pottery?
Are there moko?
Is it allowed to exchange the moko?
Comment: Moko are used in bride price, they are the property of the clan, we cannot sell them. If we do, we are stealing from the clan.

Feature: Are there people who make new moko?
Are there traditional music instruments?
Comment: mouth harp, thin bamboo (long, short), flute, bells on ankles (women: yaau) and arond calves (men gilan), gongs, long drum (2-3 meter), short drum.

Feature: Are there particular traditional music styles?
Comment: lego-lego dances and songs, planting songs, harvest songs.

Feature: Do people use body paint or tattoo?
Were teeth traditionally filed? (i.e. made shorter with a file)
Comment: In the past this was a sign that a girl / boy could marry.

Feature: Are there typical traditional haircuts?
Comment: In the past the men wore their hair on top of their head in a kind of long vertical bun, called piid. Women wore their hair as they do now.

Feature: Traditional piercings?
Comment: Only in the ears, also for men (in the past), wearing earrings for a man meant that he was a honoured person.

Feature: Are feathers or beads used as adornments?
Comment: Feathers are used in lego-lego (men), women wear necklaces (bof).

Feature: Is there traditional jewelry?
Comment: Necklaces, see previous question. Head band from beads, in the past from daun kolin ?? clip 11, 2:50

Feature: Is there special adornment used in rituals or ceremonies?
Comment: Lego lego, see above

Feature: Is spatial organization divided into primary and secondary type?
Comment: East: war dan 'sun rises', war ba'an  'sun falls', no words for North and South: the N-S dimension is taqas (ta = sea), uyan ma gi 'go to the mountains' = South, bof ma gi 'go to the coast' = North.

Feature: Are there conceptual connections between spatial directions such as E+S / W + N with male/female, or with day/night, or with right/left?
Comment: war=sun, wur=moon; war get ga'an masar, wur ga'an eqar. ta' eqar: sea male (North, Madar), ta' masar sea femal (South, Tamalabang)

Feature: Do adults in this village typically speak more than one local language?
Comment: Tamalabang is on the coast and people tend to also speak Kaera (Dorit) which is spoken nextdoor. Sometimes also Sar. In Lebang in the mountains people tend to speak just Teiwa.

Feature: Do children typically speak more than one local language?
Comment: Children speak Indonesian and Teiwa, but in many homes the children just speak Indonesian.

Feature: Is it common in this village that husband and wife have different languages?
Comment: There are mixed marriages here, but as the community is Teiwa, the newcomer must learn Teiwa. But some people don't, they speak Indonesian.

Feature: Does a wife learn to speak the language of her husband?
Comment: Because the wife moves in with the Teiwa clan of her husband

Feature: Does a husband learn to speak the language of his wife?
Comment: It happens that a husband from outside moves into the Teiwa community and he will learn some Teiwa but he doesn't have to.

Feature: Do they communicate with a third language?
Comment: They will use Indonesian but if the wife learns Teiwa they will talk Teiwa.

Feature: Do people traditionally hunt?
Comment: They hunt with bow and arrow, parang, using dogs. They hunt pigs and deer, we stand in their way and shoot them. Iu raaq = to hunt, os ma tas 'to stand in the way of game/prey'.Wutan qafalat = bow & arrow. Peed = parang. Today only 10% of the people go hunting, as there are very few pigs left in the forest.

Feature: Do people traditionally fish in the sea?
Comment: Teiwa people come from the mountains, we don't usually go fishing. In the past, we exchanged tuak, fire wood, pisang, ubi kayu for fish at the beach.

Feature: Do people traditionally have animal husbandry?
Comment: pigs, goat, chicken. In the past there were also sheep, till the 1950's. 100% of the people.

Feature: Do people traditionally have agriculture?
Comment: In the mountains: corn, rice, beans, ubi, ubi kayu, keladi, potatoes; at the beach: only ubi kayu.

Feature: Intensity of cultivation?
Comment: banana, coconut, mango, lokondari (?), kemiri, ai nonak, enau palm,

Feature: Major crops?
Comment: corn, dry rice

Feature: Are there clans?
Comment: The following clans are mentioned: Teiwa-Salanggalu (king's clan), Luaq, Quandul, Deigalu, Qaqalau, Lau Wan, Lau Uaad, Di'an Lau, Kaleman goqar, Motasu'an, Keilapi, Lambaar, Baraqala. These clans all speak Teiwa, but they have different ancestors (see answer to question 11.1).

Feature: Are there moieties?
Comment: A moiety is described a large family. There are many moieties in the clans mentioned above, too many to list.

Feature: Is there a concept of 'house' (uma/rumah) that equals a descent group?
Comment: Teiwa-Salanggalu is referred to as the yab metuu 'rumah sulung', 'eldest house'

Feature: Are clans matrilineal
Are clans, subclans or lineages ranked
Comment: Teiwa-Salanggalu is the suku rai, 'king'

Feature: Does every clan speak their own language?
Is real property (land) inherited?
Comment: The eldest son inherits everything but it is not really  his property but the moiety/family's; he has to take care of it and can give it to people to use.

Feature: Did one person (lord / clan) originally own all the land?
Comment: The land is owned by the larger family. It is divided among the sons of a family but these people do not own it. There is no personal property of land.

Feature: Did one person (lord / clan) originally own all the land?
Comment: The eldest son. But moko and gong remain the property of the moiety/family.

Feature: Are there inheritance rules?
Is land inheritance matrilineal (sister's sons; sister's younger brother)?
Is land inheritance patrilineal (sons)?
Is moveable property inheritance matrilineal (sister's sons; sister's younger brother)?
Is moveable property inheritance patrilineal?
Do all children inherit, sons and daughters alike?
Comment: Only eldest son.

Feature: Do all children inherit, with daughters receiving less?
Can newcomers aquire land or gardens?
Comment: Land or gardens are  never sold/bought. Land  is divided and we can all use it to grow food to eat. Newcomers can also use land and make a garden. If someone from elsewhere marries to someone here and comes to live with us, he is considered a child of us and can use our land.

Feature: At what age should young people get married?
Comment: In the past, boys had to learn how to hunt, have a garden, and so on, so they would marry at the age of 25-30. Girls would marry in their twenties.

Feature: Are there marriage rules – specify in notes field
Comment: There are rules as to which clan can marry which clan: Teiwa Salanggalu cannot maary Deigalu, Motasu'an, Keilapi, or Baraqala. The first three clans are servant clans. Ego cannot marry child of FB ('bapa') or MS ('mama'). [Hadar dewar nat; kasih balik tangga]. The ideal match is between ego and child of FS (tanta) or MB ('om') child.

Feature: Is there gift exchange between bride's and groom's sides?
Is there bride service?
Comment: When brideprice has not yet been paid, a couple can still marry. But the bride's family will remember the debt. If she has a brother that will get married a few years later, they will come to the groom to help pay the brideprice of his brother in law.

Feature: Transfer of residence at marriage?
Comment: In the past, the couple would move into the house of the husband's father. There would be rooms for various households in one big house,  with each their own cooking place (qaras 'tungku').

Feature: Marital residence with kin?
Comment: They can live on their own if they want to.

Feature: Are traditional marriages obligatorily exogamous?
If mother dies, who raises the children?
Possible Values: 12:Father and his family.;10:Father and/or his family;11:Mother and/or her family

Feature: Does a man typically marry a woman of his mother's subclan?
Comment: The best fit is his FS daughter.

Feature: Does a woman typicaly marry a man of her father’s subclan?
Comment: The best fit is her MB son.

Feature: Are there locality-based restrictions on marriage
Was polygamy permitted
Comment: Multiple wives are called tapas: tapas matuu 'first (kakak) wife', tapas iik 'second (adik) wife', tapas yesraq 'seventh wife'. There used to be a king with 7 wives. A single wife is called emaq.

Feature: Was polyandry permitted?
Is bridewealth paid by the groom's side to the bride's side
Comment: Eqar go'oi pin 'pay bridewealth (eqar go'oi)'. Moko, gong, rice, pig, goat.

Feature: Is dowry paid by the bride's side to the groom's side
Comment: dowry: panian ga'it taraxa [3;00 clip 4]. Clothes and stuff for the kitchen.

Feature: Are villages the typical settlement pattern?
Comment: In the past, more than 100 years ago, an extended family (3-4 families) would live in the forest and move every time looking for new land. But now everyone stays in the village.

Feature: Are dispersed solitary family homesteads the typical settlement pattern?
Are settlements permanent?
Are villages/hamlets centered on a group of related women
Mean size of local communities?
Comment: Thousand or more in Tamalabang (Lebang not included)

Feature: Are villages/hamlets centered on a group of related men?
Comment: The village is of the clans mentioned, it is not necessarily so that the houses are centered on a group of related men, it can be mixed.

Feature: Are villages/hamlets (traditionally) located on hill tops?
Are villages/hamlets (tradtionally) located on the shore?
Comment: Only since the 1960s do the Teiwa live on the shore here. Beginning of clip 5 a story about how the Teiwa found a place to live in the mountains. And a story about how the name Teiwa 'leaf of tree' was given to a baby that was born on leafs.

Feature: Do villages have places or spaces for gatherings?
Comment: place for lego-lego, building adat meetings (rumah sulung); mount of stones functioning as altar

Feature: Shape of (traditional) houses?
Floor level of traditional houses?
Comment: About 1 meter high.

Feature: Shape of roof of traditional houses?
Is there an attic or loft in a traditional house?
Comment: store food, and moko (in the rumah sulung).

Feature: Do leaders come from particular lineages?
Comment: Each clan has its leader. Patrilineal.

Feature: Are leaders non-hereditary?
Comment: They must 'be able to talk' and 'have many moko'.

Feature: Are there groups with whom traditional relations are forbidden?
Are there groups with whom there has been war?
Comment: Yes, Lau Wan had war with a brother clan (no-one knows anymore which clan this was because it is forbidden to talk about it as it was a war between brothers). Lau Wan asked help from the Teiwa clan. Lau Wan lost the fight but because the Teiwa got the victory they were given the power that Lau Wan first had. The heads of the enemy in that war are put at a place near Lebang that is called Pra war get and they are there till now.

Feature: Is there an opposition between people of the interior and people of the shore?
Comment: The Teiwa are originally mountain people, not people of the shore.

Feature: Are there female community/clan leaders
Are there men’s houses
Are there (traditional)   rulers/kings?
Comment: There is a ruler clan, and within that clan a ruler. This is hereditary, from father to son.

Feature: Are there slaves?
Comment: The notion slave is not correct, because they also have rights. They are more like servants. S there are servant clans, whose task is e.g. to get tuak (from the enau palm), or cook during the traditional talks. Examples include Kei Lapi, Mota su'an, and Deigalu clan. They are not allowed to take part in the  discussion, and if they want to marry, the Teiwa-Salanggalu ruler clan organizes this. They are not allowed to take part in traditional discussions about bride price etc. but must e.g. organize the food, or go invite guests.

Feature: Is there a concept for both ruler and foreigner, stranger king?
Are there traditional relations/alliances with one or more neighbouring groups?
Comment: These connections mostly relate to marriage. There are also barter relations with W Pantar or Blagar or Baranusa (to get cloth).

Feature: Is there a special name for this alliance?
Comment: Qawal 'friend'.

Feature: Is namesake ritually marked, or with features reminiscent of particular kinship relations?
Comment: Mother and baby stay in the house for 40 days and are not allowed to come  out. After 40 days the family makes a path of white ash where the mother walks on, to the place where the baby is washed. After washing the baby, there is a big party with the family. Then the baby is given a name; all the names of ancestors are called out, and when the baby stops crying with a particular name, that is the name he will get. Only names of ancestors that have already died are used. This is a different name as the name given at baptism, which is from the bible, although today people start giving traditional names when babies are baptized.
Possible Values: 10:Given Abui name upon birth given by  parents;0:No;1:Yes

Feature: Do descent groups own sets of personal names?
Comment: The name of a clan or moietie is the second name, not the personal name. But since personal names relate to ancestors, they tend to occur in certain families.

Feature: Are names taken from the father's group?
Are names taken from the mother's group?
Are there name taboos?
Are there particular relations not to be addressed, or mentioned, by name
Comment: Older people are not to be addressed by personal name. For a man, the family name must be preceded by Kri, for a woman by Quaf.

Feature: did your language (or a group of people defined by speaking the language) traditionally have a name, other than a locality name
Comment: Sometimes the language is also referred to as Lebang tarau,  or Madar tarau, i.e. referring to the place where it is spoken.

Feature: Is there a special word to refer to a foreigner?
Comment: We refer to them by the place name + wal or oqar. White people are referred to as uy miaq 'white people',  or Walan'da 'Holland'.
